title: Verizon Small Business Digital Ready Grant Program (Current Round)
description: This program awards 50 grants of $10,000 each to eligible U.S. small businesses upon completion of required digital readiness courses and resources.
detailed_overview: This grant program is offered through the Verizon Small Business Digital Ready platform, in partnership with LISC, to complement the free resources provided. The current round aims to award 50 small businesses with $10,000 grants. To access the application, owners must register and complete a combination of two eligible courses or events between July 1, 2025, and December 10, 2025. Since 2021, the program has awarded $14 million in total grants.
eligibility: Owners of for-profit small businesses based in the U.S., Puerto Rico, or US Virgin Islands. Nonprofits are not eligible. Applicants may apply for one business only and must be over the age of 18.
application_requirements: Must register and complete the Digital Ready resources
Complete any combination of two eligible courses or events between July 1, 2025 and December 10, 2025 to unlock the application
Submission of the final application by the deadline
geography: U.S., Puerto Rico, or US Virgin Islands

title: Digitizing Hidden Collections: Amplifying Unheard Voices
funder: CLIR (Council on Library and Information Resources)
description: This program supports nonprofit organizations in the US and Canada to digitize rare and unique materials from hidden collections, specifically aiming to amplify unheard or underrepresented voices.
detailed_overview: The *Digitizing Hidden Collections: Amplifying Unheard Voices* grant program supports projects that digitize rare and unique materials held by eligible organizations. The program aims to make these collections publicly accessible, focusing on those materials that can amplify unheard voices or underrepresented perspectives. The application process begins with an Initial Application. Two or more eligible organizations may apply to collaborate, but one must be appointed as the lead applicant responsible for project oversight and fund management. The program is specifically designed for nonprofit academic, independent, and community-based organizations in the US and Canada that collect, preserve, and share such materials.
eligibility:
This program is for nonprofit academic, independent, and community-based organizations in the US and Canada that collect, preserve, and share rare and unique materials with the general public. Eligible organizations must propose eligible projects falling within the program’s scope and be prepared to abide by the program’s award terms.

Applicant organizations and any collaborating organizations must fall under one of the following categories and meet the requirements for that category:
* US organizations that fit the above description must also be tax-exempt under
  + IRS Code Section 501(c)3;
  + IRS Code Section 115; or
  + IRS Code Section 170(c)1.
* Canadian organizations that fit the above description must be
  + a current registered charity listed by the Canada Revenue Agency; and/or
  + a designated educational institution recognized as eligible to receive Canada Student Loans.
* Federal, state, provincial, territorial, municipal, tribal, or indigenous government units may also be eligible, provided they can present evidence that collecting, preserving, and sharing rare and unique materials with the general public is part of the purpose and normal functioning of the unit. Government organizations should email hiddencollections@clir.org and confirm their ability to demonstrate eligibility before preparing and submitting a proposal.

Two or more eligible organizations may apply to collaborate on a project. When two or more organizations collaborate, one must be appointed as the lead applicant, accepting responsibility for project oversight and the management of grant funds. Eligible projects must support the digitization of rare and unique materials.
application_requirements: Submission of the Initial Application form during an open call for applications
Project must fall within the program's scope (digitization of hidden collections)
US applicants must demonstrate 501(c)3, 115, or 170(c)1 tax-exempt status
Canadian applicants must be a registered charity or designated educational institution
Government units must confirm eligibility with CLIR Grants Team prior to submission
Designation of a lead applicant for collaborative projects

title: CLIR Application Announcement for Digitizing Hidden Collections (Deadline Oct 20, 2025)
funder: CLIR (Council on Library and Information Resources)
